comments.commentBody: Yes, I've been wondering how many footballers will die in Qatar.
And Dennis Hastert has long had the right to shower with your teenage son. What was your point again?
The graffiti will be lewd, rude crude and written in multi colored shades of ink.
Your comment highlights why adults should teach children to respect others and should never condone bullying.  The antics you allude to are unacceptable under all circumstances.

I see no problem with girls in the boys bathroom at school. After all, they squat to pee and there will be private stalls (albeit with a few cracks in the door). But how can the boys use the girls bathroom where there will be no urinals.You certainly don't expect those growing young men to squat do you? Just like at home they will splatter pee all over the walls and seat (which of course will be down). And they will expect Mommy to clean it up! Ohhh, you don't think so?? Then you have never been in Army boot camp.

I wish they would have let me go in the girls bathroom when I was a kid. Even then we thought up lots of mean tricks to play like pounding on the walls and writing nasty stuff on the door. Oh what fun this is going to be for the new crop of little boys. Glue on the seat? That kind of stuff. Wait, you aren't counting on the boys not trying to claim they are transgender are you? If you are then you have never been in elementary school.

More dangerous than what? Causing MANY transgender people stress every time they have to go to the bathroom? That will contribute very negatively to people's mental health and quality of life. We all share bathrooms at home. This would be no different. You need help in the first place if you're obsessed with other people's genitals in public bathrooms. Laws against transgender access will not prevent sickos from being sickos.

Transgender people are not a protected class under federal law. Congress writes law, not the President. Your comparison to women's suffrage is faulty. The Administration has neither attempted to pass a new law nor a constitutional amendment. They are using the "because I said so" logic which works quite well with children but not such much with free citizens.

It is not discrimination to have restrooms and changing areas that are separated by biological sex.

I agree with much of what you say. But democratic processes include more than simply voting every four years. True democratic leadership sets up democratic processes that listen and integrate and revise and correct rather than simply issuing edicts. It works with the society and culture and the sincere concerns of citizens. This is an instance in which we need democratic culture to work.

There are disagreements and misunderstandings that could be worked through with more discussion. For example, I do not agree that the edict in this case is similar to the process of women's winning the right to vote. I also do not believe that the civil rights analogies are correct. The AG makes it sound as if having "Male" and "Female" rest rooms is equivalent to segregation and Jim Crow. I also do not believe that the issue of locker rooms and the repercussions more broadly have been thought through. I could change my mind on some issues, but the federal government has decided that it is morally and culturally superior to us citizens and doesn't have to respect our benighted concerns. Instead it will use its power and force over us. I agree that this is bold, but I also believe that pushing the issue so far beyond transgender rights and dignity threatens the effort to protect trans people's rights and dignity, as well as the rights and dignity of non-trans citizens. I believe that it is a bad decision. It comes partly from the blindness and felt superiority of having power.

@Jesse: you do not seem to understand how a CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT becomes part of our laws.

The 19th Amendment was not handed down by a President or a King or a dictator....it was not a Presidential executive order. It was PASSED BY CONGRESS and then sent to all 48 states (in 1919) and RATIFIED.

Since this is a republic, and we have representatives in Congress and state legislatures....yes, it was absolutely passed by a vote of the people in a totally democratic way.

It is not remotely like gay marriage, which was IMPOSED by social engineering courts and legislatures....directly AGAINST votes by the people to keep traditional marriage.

Those lawmakers in NC are standing up for the rights of ordinary people. They are heroes. I expect to see other states follow their lead.

Why are the people not consulted in such matters, we have children. Why are such Edicts passed down to us. Are we a Democratic country at all. The nation should have been allowed to vote if marriage other than that between a man and a woman is to be allowed. Are we in a Dictatorship. If we refuse, no state funding. WHAT is going on!!!!!Why are we being imposed with such Laws, why are we not consulted....allowed to vote on such matters.
So you would integrate sports too?  Why not end male basketball and women's basketball teams. Just have a basketball league open to all and you will never see a woman grace that court ever again.

If you consider sex to be an inherent part of transgenderism, then you don't understand it and shouldn't be offering uninformed opinions about it. Some transgendered people like males and some like females and some are bisexual, irrespective of what their gender identity or original biological sex was.

Why are you so obsessed with sex so as to bring it up when it's not relevant to the topic at hand?
Way to put down the countryside, Jersey.

Actually, you can just go to the bathroom in your own home if you wish to avoid possibly peeing next to a transgender person. Public restrooms, intended to serve the general public, must not discriminate based on your discomforts. It continues to astound me how many people just don't get it: you don't get to push other people around and carve out safe zones for yourself that infringe on the freedom of fellow citizens and call it your "right." Your rights only extend as far as they do not infringe on the rights of others. Classic premise; little understood these days. The Amish have understood this for hundreds of years, withdrawing from society and minimizing contact with outsiders.  You are free to do the same.
You are so naive.
Yes, of course we were.  Do you seriously question that?
Was MLK fighting for a real minority or a fabricated one?
Not locker areas, Jeff.  Bathrooms.  And since this isn't Afghanistan, we don't squat around a hole in the floor - it's private in there, with stalls.  You've used one, right?
What rights are you losing? Please, do tell.

We can argue about this or that.  But when you say 99% of the people support your position, I have to think you're living in some kind of a bubble.  P.S.  I suppose a lot of people still feel "uncomfortable" around people with HIV.  If you say transgender kids aren't beaten and scorned, you're a very cruel person.  Personally I wouldn't care if all restrooms were co-ed where adults are concerned.  I think I would know how to act.  If you're afraid of rapists, don't let women leave their homes.
Um, I'm pretty sure urinals are not private...

Just mimicking the lie to make yourself feel less homophobic.

The lie is that trans people are more dangerous than non-trans. Please google "republican sexually abused boys" and look at the long list that follows then pretend that you and your party of freaks are the sane ones.

Bill, you swallow propaganda too easily.  Has Hillary ever let her investors lose their money by bankrupting her businesses?  Don't bother yelling "Benghazi Benghazi E-mails!"; those are thoroughly discredited attacks -- just like "Whitewater!"
Ryan, it's too easy to try to insult Snowden with inapplicable words like "patron", instead of paying attention to the anti-democratic activities of your own government.

No.  This is like the tail wagging the dog.  Instead of expecting the overwhelming majority of the population to make accommodations for a small special interest group, the last two of your suggestions should be offered to the transgender community.  Of course they would be as insulted by such nonsense as anyone else.

People have three options:
1) Use restroom for its intended purposes and disregard other people's private parts, since you should be doing that in the first place.
2) Use the restroom at home /private or shared hotel room lodging .
3) Wear a disposable adult diaper / underwear garment and deal with the snickers by those laugh at people who wear such garments.

Generally speaking, when people do not have civil rights, they don't especially enjoy having a waiting period while other people take their chill pills.

Transgender people did not suddenly appear out of nowhere. Discrimination against us did not just start as some bad experiment yesterday. Like all people who get trodden on, we've been trodden on for longer than enough. Not going to wait around for people to untwist their impressions and go through years of niceties when they're standing in front of the bathroom door claiming to have a reason that I can't pee.

If you'd like to gain comfort with transgender people, there are a variety of contributory ways you could go about meeting us and coming to terms with our existence and our realities. That might be easier and more rewarding for all of us than obsessing about the bathroom.

Excuse me? "Don't ask, don't tell" was a disaster. And when Jim Crow laws could not be struck down by "winning hearts and minds," the Feds stepped in and smacked down Little Rock with one rule: "This girl was going to school." So take that history lesson and smoke it.
Your whole life has been the trial. Trans people have always existed and they have been using the correct bathroom all along.  The proof is that you never noticed them!

Too bad we can't have a sort of "don't ask don't tell" transition period like we did with gays in the military.  Even many non-bigoted people (like me) had concerns about how it would work out so don't ask was a good trial period.  Turned out now even people from places prone to bigotry don't object to gays in the military.  We muddled through and got to a perfect result.  The way Obama is handling this seems intended to polarize and make people dig in their heels which is the exactly what you don't want.  In any social cause the best strategy is to win hearts and minds  not smack them down with rules.

The abuse of this policy will usher in more issues than the progressive groups can even fathom...of course with progressive ideals it isn't out come but intentions that matter. So I guess I shouldn't be surprised they deflect the main and legitimate cause of concern with "bigotry" or "transphobe" rhetoric instead of address concerns and actually take a real look at the counter arguments against. Irony is they are calling everyone else bigots...

It actually goes in reverse almost as much. Girls are not some innocent pure creature, they are sometimes the worse aggressors.
I agree that the bathrooms should be separated as to simply create a social barrier to reduce the surface area of abuse and voyeurism.

Yes, we do know that, because the policy requires parental recognition of the child's gender identity and parental consent to use the restroom the child identifies with.  Ir ian't something any kid will be able to do on the fly, or for cheap thrills.

Statistically women are more apt to abuse children. We just hear about men more often because of double standards in our legal system and society.
So while, from a security stand point, yes there is a risk with men and boys sharing the same bathroom, locker room, changing room, by allowing women in the mens area you are increasing the risk of attack on boys, voyeurism etc even more.
So explain to me why we should increase the chances instead of reduce them? Remember this goes the other way with women's restrooms, locker rooms etc as well. We've just increased our surface area of attack, congrats on not thinking.
